title: Benefits cheat stole £52,000 despite having more than £500,000 in the bank
text:
Gloucester Crown Court heard Karen Spice, 61, accepted benefits for five years despite having half a million pounds in savings (Picture: PA)

A wealthy woman who stole £52,000 in benefits despite owning more than half a million pounds has been spared jail for the sake of her two adult sons.

Benefits cheat Karen Spice, 61, was accused of ‘milking the system to the last drop’ by claiming housing benefit, Council Tax reduction and Council Tax benefits for five years.

She failed to tell Cheltenham Borough Council that during that time, she had savings of £558,000.

Spice, a relationship councillor from Witney, Oxfordshire, was spared jail by on the grounds she does an ‘important job’ and has two sons who need her support because they have not yet got over their father’s death seven years ago.

She pleaded guilty to three charges of fraud for claiming £52,373 in benefits between October 2011 and October 2016.

Prosecutor Nicholas Lee said: ‘Any savings over £16,000 have to be declared to the council by those claiming benefits and this defendant had access to £558,000.

‘She failed to disclose this and also failed to tell the council of a change in her financial circumstances despite regular written annual requests to do so.’

Mum had no idea 'funny' tasting wine was first sign of heart attack

The court heard that Spice had 12 different bank accounts, including seven set up with Coventry Building Society.

But when asked by the council, who had been investigating her, if she had an account with the bank she said no.

Mr Lee added: ‘She was milking the system to the last drop. She tried to disguise her finances and this was a persistent fraud over a length of time.

‘The defendant now lives in a mortgage-free house in Oxfordshire.’

Defending lawyer Sarah Jenkins said Spice split from the father of her children in 2000 and he died in 2012.

Spice was claiming housing benefit, Council Tax reduction and Council Tax benefits for five years (Picture: Getty)

A ‘significant’ amount of her wealth was inherited from her mother and Spice wanted to buy a house with it ‘to provide security for her and her children and the two sons who still live with her’.

The defence lawyer said Spice’s two grown-up sons had never got over the death of their father and added that she has now paid back all of the £52,373 fraudulently claimed.

She told the court that there was ‘no element of a lavish lifestyle’ in this case.

Sentencing Spice to a 12-month suspended prison sentence and 200 hours of unpaid work, Judge Ian Lawrie QC said her offending was ‘reprehensible’.

He said: ‘She has been fleecing the taxpayer out of thousands of pounds.

‘So many people in this country are on the breadline and she is sitting on her savings, which are denied to so many people.’

The judge told Spice: ‘You deserve to go to custody but you are not going to.

‘You indulged in dishonesty for a significant period and creamed more than £50,000 from the system.

‘But the job you do is important and your two grown-up sons are still struggling to get over their father’s death.’

Spice was also ordered to pay £340 prosecution costs.
